name: NPR
text:
President Trump directly contradicted the CDC director Robert Redfield's timeline for a COVID-19 vaccine, saying Redfield's prediction of mid-2021 for widespread distribution was "a mistake."
https://t.co/hgXmAqRNvT

name: NPR
text:
RT @timkmak: New: Documents obtained by NPR show military police considered deploying non-lethal 'heat ray' against protesters in Lafayette Square: 

https://t.co/JuAIBEdsdl

name: NPR
text:
The Bobcat Fire came within 500 feet of LA's Mount Wilson Observatory, the site of major 20th-century scientific discoveries, but crews successfully fought off the blaze.
https://t.co/dYBw4RdndI

name: NPR
text:
Joe Biden on Wednesday said if he's elected president any future COVID-19 vaccine would be distributed equitably and provided first to those at greatest risk.
https://t.co/6diXEv6Xdu

name: NPR
text:
The pandemic has sped up a major shift toward freelancing — as people turn to it out of necessity.

The proportion of the U.S. workforce that performs freelance work has increased to 36% by one estimate.
https://t.co/HiUY28HH4q

name: NPR
text: Today on #NPRConsiderThis, six months after Breonna Taylor was killed by police in Louisville, Ky., the city settled a civil lawsuit for $12 million. Taylor's family and friends remember who she was before she became the face of a movement. https://t.co/Cp8HwSePgA

name: NPR
text:
Larry Wilmore has a resume that could rival pretty much anyone's in Hollywood:
- Insecure
- In Living Color
- The Office
- The Daily Show
- The Nightly Show

Now, Wilmore is back in the hosting chair with a new show on the NBC streaming service Peacock. https://t.co/V9qhG7upPy

name: NPR
text: .@radioambulante, nuestro podcast en español, está de vuelta con una nueva temporada. Escuchen el primer episodio: un “juego de niños”. https://t.co/8fiBQWQTOV

name: NPR
text:
Scientists have reproduced the altered state often associated with the drug ketamine by inducing certain brain cells to fire together in a slow, rhythmic fashion with the use of light.
https://t.co/hP7fWtS2R2

name: NPR
text:
An immigrant woman who alleges that one of her fallopian tubes was removed without her consent at an ICE detention center in Georgia was nearly deported on Wednesday.

Members of Congress say they intervened while she was on the tarmac.
https://t.co/IaIsaXx34M

name: NPR
text:
President Trump has cast fresh doubt on any deal to keep TikTok in the country.

Trump also said he had been informed that there's "no legal path" for the U.S. to get a cut of whatever deal the government approves — an idea he had floated previously.
https://t.co/csDg2C8J8X

name: NPR
text:
Six months into the coronavirus pandemic, the U.S. still isn't making enough N95 masks and other PPE to satisfy soaring demand.

Smaller domestic manufacturers could help, but it's a risky move.
https://t.co/7Fzs6pvwyx

name: NPR
text: RT @MorningEdition: Pennsylvania is a state to watch this election season. Today @NPRinskeep and @_RyanBenk are reporting out of Pittsburgh, asking African American voters where they stand with the presidential candidates. https://t.co/A8DloY15su

name: NPR
text: RT @nprmusic: Dropping Oct. 8, our new podcast @LouderThanARiot tracks the interconnected rise of hip-hop and mass incarceration. Hosted by @rodneyology and @Sid_Madden, each episode explores an artist's story, tracing the collision between rhyme and punishment. https://t.co/aqV5KJlV2x https://t.co/E7vwFq0Z5P

name: NPR
text:
Rep. Bennie Thompson condemned acting DHS secretary Chad Wolf for failing to appear in response to a House subpoena — saying the move "should appall every member of this committee."
https://t.co/Izz0TL3Ccv

name: NPR
text:
FBI Director Christopher Wray tells Congress that terrorism dangers in the U.S. have evolved from those with foreign plotters abroad to those involving homegrown and domestic extremists.
https://t.co/TRBjelkZUG

name: NPR
text:
In remarks to a largely conservative audience yesterday, Attorney General Bill Barr called restrictions imposed during the global pandemic "the greatest intrusion on civil liberties in American history" since slavery.
https://t.co/9LeQPiUTdQ

name: NPR
text:
Since 1938, U.S. labor laws have carved out a special rule for people with disabilities, saying they can be paid less than minimum wage.

Now, the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights says that exemption has been abused and should be phased out.
https://t.co/8XX2N6GS3W

name: NPR
text:
RT @alinaselyukh: For 82 years U.S. labor law has said workers with disabilities can be paid less than minimum wage. A top federal civil-rights watchdog now says the law needs change, because it's been trapping workers in "exploitative and discriminatory" job programs.
https://t.co/gkOT1Y92dy

name: NPR
text:
RT @throughlineNPR: As issues of systemic racism and police brutality continue to arise, America is being pushed to confront itself. But these conversations are not new.

How the work of writer James Baldwin can help navigate the current moment: https://t.co/GC4PeCLewv https://t.co/TmKAGrFUCq

name: NPR
text:
At least one person has died as a result of Hurricane Sally, which is now a tropical depression.

Forecasters are warning of "widespread flash flooding and minor to moderate river flooding" in parts of Georgia and South Carolina.
https://t.co/FK3gBUBTiH

name: NPR
text:
Members of Congress are demanding an investigation into allegations that immigrants were subjected to medical procedures without their consent while detained at an ICE facility.

Some women say they underwent surgeries that left them sterile.
https://t.co/Hm6kgitAcO

name: NPR
text:
In a year when Americans are thinking about recession, a pandemic, racial justice, climate change and policing, many Trump voters — or potential Trump voters — are bringing up abortion in explaining their voting decisions.
https://t.co/6eJVun6WNX

name: NPR
text:
India now has more than 5 million coronavirus cases — and the world's highest daily count of new infections.

It's on track, within weeks, to surpass the United States as the worst-affected country in the world.
https://t.co/qCOtbR6ToS

name: NPR
text:
Across the U.S., people are skipping medical care because of failing finances or fear of the coronavirus, doctors say. Others find medical practices closed to new patients.

And many are suffering health consequences, an NPR poll finds.
https://t.co/to9uSYrdoo

name: NPR
text:
A Salt Lake City police officer faces a felony charge after ordering a police dog to attack a Black man who was on his knees with his hands raised. 

The man’s injuries were so severe he required surgery, reports @KUER. https://t.co/SzYj2RPd7i

name: NPR
text:
In a national survey, about half of teachers across the U.S. said they had their own kids under the age of 18 at home.

Of those teachers, 57% agreed with the statement: "I cannot properly do my job from home while also taking care of my children."
https://t.co/fzDg57PGYG

name: NPR
text:
A federal judge says the winding down of the 2020 census must remain on hold through Sept. 24 at the latest — throwing door-knocking efforts further into uncertainty during what could be the final days of counting. 
https://t.co/BDoBCRr6mj

name: NPR
text:
The West's plummeting air quality is forcing many agricultural workers to choose between prioritizing their health or earning badly needed money.

"The truth is that I have to work," one says. "I pray I stay healthy." She doesn't have health insurance.  
 https://t.co/50GSHuEfsH

name: NPR
text:
Many museums are still closed — but their shops are selling face masks based on their collections. You can mask up with a Monet, a van Gogh or, perhaps best suited to These Times: Edvard Munch's The Scream. 😱
https://t.co/Cuw7GPy38S

name: NPR
text:
RT @npratc: Campaigns and political parties have staffed up their legal war rooms ahead of this election season, making it one of the most litigated ever. Today on #NPRConsiderthis, we look at the lawsuits already filed and what might come next.
https://t.co/6EpEL2pNL5

name: NPR
text:
The Pennsylvania Supreme Court extended the deadline for accepting mail ballots, will allow ballot drop boxes and removed the Green Party's presidential candidate from the ballot — decisions that are likely to help Democrats this fall.
https://t.co/IYLjZydiB7
